results.title: Hang onto yourself: no fun
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Dancing in the street: a rock and roll history”.
In ‘Hang onto yourself’, this episode features an in-depth look at the many faces of David Bowie, particularly as the glam phenomena Ziggy Stardust. The rise of performers such as Alice Cooper, Lou Reed and Ziggy is seen as a response to the hangover from the summer of love where rock developed theatricality. The rise of Reggae and Punk music is the subject of the episode entitled ‘No fun’ and features clips and interviews with pivotal figures such as Malcolm McClaren, The Sex Pistols, Bob Marley and Talking Heads.

results.title: Handsome Serge = Le Beau Serge
results.brief_description: After ten years away, Francois returns to the village where he grew up and meets up with his old friend Serge. Serge used to be the envy of all because of his intelligence and beauty, but he is now only a shadow of his former self. Married to Yvonne, Serge has become an alcoholic after the couple lost their child. Francois is willing to do anything to help his friend, and the two protagonists indulge in a transfer of personal guilt, then an exchange of redemption. “Le Beau Serge” was the first film of French critic-turned-director Claude Chabrol and is widely acknowledged as the first film of the French New Wave. Two of the principal actors - Jean-Claude Brialy and Gerard Blain - also appear in Chabrol’s follow-up film, “Les Cousins”. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Hands, knees and bumps-a-daisy
results.creator_credit: TV Cartoons and National Coal Board
results.brief_description: A short and amusing animated industrial safety film in which Stanley Unwin exhorts his audience to safeguard themselves against injury in their work by wearing the protective gloves and knee-pads provided. Also considers the hazards of working in mines.

results.title: Hands up = Rece do gory [NTSC]
results.brief_description: This film was made in 1967. For 14 years it was banned by the censorship. In choosing its present form I am treating it as a diary to see if along this ago record and jottings from spring 1981 can answer the questions: Who were we? Who are we?…Jerzy Skolimowski Jerzy Skolimowski, Polish filmmaker renowned for his political messages and innovative filmmaking, wrote, directed and starred in this rather unusual, somewhat surreal, and yet quite compelling film. The plot centres around five doctors (four men and a woman) who meet up at a medical school reunion during the mid-sixties, ten years after their graduation. A set of circumstances eventually leads the five to finding themselves on board a sealed railway carriage where a drama of a psychological kind begins to be played out by each of the protagonists. Bitter memories of the Stalinist Communist regime which ruled Poland during the 1950s and the effects it had on their profession are re-enacted over and over in their minds and are played out in a drunken haze as each of the five try to come to terms with the past. Cast includes Jerzy Skolimowski, Joanna Szczerbic, Tadeusz Lomnicki, Adam Hanuszkiewicz, Bogumil Kobiela, Margarethe von Trotta, with guest appearances by Alan Bates, Fred Zinneman, Jane Asher, David Essex.

results.title: Hands to flying stations.
results.creator_credit: Stewart Films, John R.F. Stewart and Richard Need
results.brief_description: Life and work aboard the British aircraft carrier HMS Hermes. Outstanding features of her construction and equipment are illustrated, and both carrier and crew are seen in action when Hermes sets out for the Mediterranean on her first major exercise.

results.title: Hands of history
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Margaret Pettigrew and Loretta Todd
results.brief_description: A revealing look at four First Nations women artists in Canada, each from a different nation, who share their thoughts and opinions both as a Native American (or Aboriginal) and as an artist or creator. For each of these women the passing on of their culture, the teachings from their elders, the spiritual and the ceremonial traditions, is foremost and it is through their individual expressions of art that they are able to achieve this end. Doreen Jensen (Gitksan Indians): wood carver/designer, fascinated by totem poles and their significance in the Native American culture where family histories can be discovered by reading the totem poles. Through her printmaking, Doreen keeps her culture alive, educating others in the meaning of the artwork of the Northwest Coast. Rena Point Bolton (Stalo Indians): weaver of baskets, blankets and robes, Rena believes in passing on the teachings of her elders. Gentle and spiritual her beautifully crafted work is displayed in museums across the world. Joane Cardinal-Schubert (Blood Indians): painter and creator of installation art using multimedia combinations, Joane is confronting and political in her work, determined to educate the ignorant and redefine indigenous art to the outsider in order to keep her culture alive. Jane Ash Poitras (Chippewyan Indians): painter of sacred/spiritual works who loves to explore other worlds or realms in her creations. Believes in the spiritual healing of her art, the passing down of legends, the allowing of the outsider to pass through and experience those other worlds through her art. Evocative in vision and sound, this beautifully presented documentary includes black and white archival footage, personal narratives and portrayals of each woman’s art.

results.title: Handmaidens and battleaxes
results.brief_description: This is an informative and entertaining documentary which traces the role of nurses from pre-industrial times to the modern day. The program uses rare archival footage, dramatic re-enactments, personal interviews and photographic stills collected from nursing colleges from three continents. These elements successfully combine to give insight into the reality of the nursing profession.
